DESCRIPTION: 'Thin' of an object, not a person.  Opposite of 'thick', not of 'fat'.
EXAMPLE_CONTEXT: This piece of wood is thin, and that one is thick.
He picked fruit from the trees.
What animal does this meat come from?

DESCRIPTION: Of a gap, opposite of 'wide'.  *Not* of an object, *not* opposite of 'broad, thick'.
EXAMPLE_CONTEXT: The canyon is wide here, but further down it's narrow.

DESCRIPTION: Nail of a finger/toe, not for hammering.
EXAMPLE_CONTEXT: He had very long nails on his fingers.
What is your name?
While fighting, he hit him on the nose.
He put his hand on his neck.
Night and day.
She was thirsty, so she drank some water.
What are you eating?
Four plus one is five.

DESCRIPTION: Opposite of 'left'.  *Not* 'correct'.  Adjective form, not adverb.
EXAMPLE_CONTEXT: He is blind in his right eye.
One could see his navel.
She wanted to cut the (insert name of local fruit). He gave her a knife.
One plus one is two.
Blood is red.
When will we meet again?
I would like to own a dog.
People can't breathe underwater.
I saw the moon in the sky.
He lives beside the river.
Everyone has a father and a mother.
You could see some of the roots of the tree above the ground.
That fruit is rotten.
Is it dry or wet?
One ear of his was bigger than the other ear.
I see him every day on the road.
That tree trunk is thick; it would take a long time cut through.
There are many animals in the forest.

DESCRIPTION: The material, not the planet.
EXAMPLE_CONTEXT: As he dug the hole, he threw out the earth.
When water freezes, it turns to ice.
An empty pot is easier to carry than a full pot. (WOLD)
That table is round.
Can you run fast?
Don't drop the egg; it will break!
He sewed the two pieces of cloth together.
I heard him yesterday. He was singing.
That is a good idea.
There is grass growing beside the river.
His skin was old and hard.
I could see the smoke from the fire.

DESCRIPTION: Hair of the head, not the body.  Of people, not of animals.
EXAMPLE_CONTEXT: She pulled him by his hair.
He burned his hand.

DESCRIPTION: Stative verb, 'be sitting', *not* change of state 'sit down'..
EXAMPLE_CONTEXT: He is sitting over there.
He spat on the ground.

DESCRIPTION: Verb for a person *perceiving* an odour.  *Not* emit a odour (intransitive).
EXAMPLE_CONTEXT: I (can) smell smoke.
It was very hard. When he bit it he broke his tooth.
The grass was fresh and green.
He cut open the animal and pulled out its guts.
There were white clouds in the blue sky.
He jumped when he saw the snake.
He has lots of hair on his head.
There were many stars in the night sky.
His heart was beating fast.
A sharp knife cuts better than a blunt one.
The rock was very heavy.
The knife is here.
She washed her hands.

DESCRIPTION: Intransitive verb, not transitive.  Most generic equivalent of 'combust' meaning.
EXAMPLE_CONTEXT: The wood is burning in the fire.
I fell from the tree yesterday and hurt my back.

DESCRIPTION: *See full meaning description.^See full meaning description.*
EXAMPLE_CONTEXT: *See full meaning description.*
Everyone has a father and a mother.

DESCRIPTION: The verb '(to) fly'.
EXAMPLE_CONTEXT: Birds can fly but people cannot.
The rocks get hot during the day and cold at night.
Where is the knife?

DESCRIPTION: Of a gap, opposite of 'narrow'.  *Not* of an object, *not* opposite of 'thick'.
EXAMPLE_CONTEXT: The canyon is wide here, but further down it's narrow.
I couldn't see the village because of the fog.
Her foot is injured so she cannot walk.
You can't walk there in one day; it's too far.
What bird does this feather come from?
He was cold, so he moved closer to the fire.
I can see a fish swimming in the water.

DESCRIPTION: The noun '(a) flower', to the verb 'bloom'.
EXAMPLE_CONTEXT: What type of flower is this?

DESCRIPTION: The noun for the insect '(a) fly'..
EXAMPLE_CONTEXT: He killed a fly.
Some animals have horns. Humans do not.
How do you make fire?
This is a short rope; that is a long rope.
He slapped his thigh.
He is digging in the ground.

DESCRIPTION: The verb '(to) bite', not the noun for '(a) bite'.
EXAMPLE_CONTEXT: The dog bit him.

DESCRIPTION: Verb for the mental activity, process of thinking; the generic term for 'cogitate, be thinking abour something'.  *Not* have an opinion.
EXAMPLE_CONTEXT: What are you doing?  I'm just thinking.
I used this knife.
She puts too much salt in her food.
Everyone dies sooner or later.
She said that she would be late.
Her house is beside the sea.
The leaves tasted bitter.
I saw him on the road. I don't know where he was coming from.
You can eat the seeds of (insert name of local fruit).
This stick is straight, but that one is bent.
The cat scratched me with its claws.
The rocks get hot during the day and cold at night.
She let the sand fall through her hands.
He fell and broke a bone.
I've cut my finger; look, it's bleeding.
This cup is clean and that one is dirty.

DESCRIPTION: Specifically an adult male, not the generic sense of 'person' or 'humankind'.
EXAMPLE_CONTEXT: I saw a man and a woman.
Charcoal is black.
She scratched her head.

DESCRIPTION: Stative verb, 'be standing', *not* change of state 'get up, stand up'.
EXAMPLE_CONTEXT: He is standing over there.
He could see his shadow on the ground.
This apple is ripe now, it tastes sweet.
There were white clouds in the blue sky.
I counted the stones; there were five stones.
The dog wagged its tail.
She carried her bag [under her arm].
Blood is red.
Day and night.
Take the money when you go.
I used that knife.
The knife is (over) there.
Three plus one is four.
I saw him on the road. I don't know where he was going.
What did you **do** in the village yesterday?
Her house is beside the lake.
He’s grinding flour.
He picked a leaf from the tree.
I heard a noise last night.

DESCRIPTION: The verb 'to (hide)', not the noun for an animal skin.
EXAMPLE_CONTEXT: They hid their food from the animals.
The ice is melting in the sun.
He put his hand on his knee.

DESCRIPTION: The verb '(to) hit', not the noun for a blow or strike.
EXAMPLE_CONTEXT: He hit the ball with the stick.

DESCRIPTION: Know a fact, *not* a person.  Be aware of not be acquainted with.
EXAMPLE_CONTEXT: They know that we’re coming.

DESCRIPTION: The verb '(to) hunt', not the noun '(a) hunt'.
EXAMPLE_CONTEXT: He’s hunting animals in the forest.

DESCRIPTION: The opposite of 'right (hand side)'.  Ajdective, not adverb.
EXAMPLE_CONTEXT: He is blind in his left eye.

DESCRIPTION: The part of the body between shoulders and stomach.  *Not* specifically the female breast.
EXAMPLE_CONTEXT: His wore a medal on his chest.
He drank because he was thirsty.
He put his fingers in his mouth.
Eat some food and drink some water.
They started fighting. He killed him.
When I saw him, he was laughing.
This is a big stone. That is a small stone.
What bird does this feather come from?

DESCRIPTION: The noun, part of the human body, not the English adjective or adverb 'back'.
EXAMPLE_CONTEXT: I fell over and now my back hurts.

DESCRIPTION: The noun for the 'bark' of a tree.  *Not* the verb for the barking of dogs!
EXAMPLE_CONTEXT: He tore some bark off the tree.
This is a long rope; that is a short rope.
He fell and broke his leg.

DESCRIPTION: Stative verb, i.e. 'be lying (down).  *Not* the English homonym 'tell untruths'.
EXAMPLE_CONTEXT: She was lying on the ground.
I picked a louse from his hair.
You can walk there in one day; it's near.

DESCRIPTION: Verb 'be alive'. *Not* 'dwell' in a place.
EXAMPLE_CONTEXT: How many years can people live for?
That's a bad idea.

DESCRIPTION: The sense of shedding tears, not shouting out.
EXAMPLE_CONTEXT: She was crying when I saw her.
When he died they found that his liver was very swollen.
There's an ant climbing up your leg.

DESCRIPTION: The  verb '(to) blow', not the noun for (a) blow from hitting.
EXAMPLE_CONTEXT: He blew on the sticks to start the fire.

DESCRIPTION: Kin term, for offspring;  *not* about young age, non-adult.  Opposite of 'parent', not of 'adult;.
EXAMPLE_CONTEXT: That is their first child.

DESCRIPTION: The powdery remains of a fire, not the tree species 'ash'.
EXAMPLE_CONTEXT: There was nothing left but ash.
He punched him in the belly.
He started to climb the mountain.
I do not understand.
While the dog was here, I was scared.
She closed one eye.
He lives in the old house, not in the new house.
He lives in the new house; not in the old house.
I saw him standing in the rain.
He is sleeping in the house.
This is a small stone. That is a big stone.
During the day, the sun is in the sky; at night, it's not.
His house is at the edge of the village.

DESCRIPTION: ^See full meaning description.*
EXAMPLE_CONTEXT: ^See full meaning description.*
There was snow on the ground.

DESCRIPTION: Noun, not adjective:  the substance.  'Fat' as opposed to muscle, bone, skin, etc..  *Not* the opposite of 'thin'.
EXAMPLE_CONTEXT: Cut the fat off the meat.
He picked a smooth stone from the river.
He is swimming in the lake.
His arm swelled after he was injured.

DESCRIPTION: The verb '(to) tie', not the noun.
EXAMPLE_CONTEXT: He tied the two sticks together.
He stuck his tongue out.

DESCRIPTION: The verb '(to) walk', not the noun '(a) walk'.
EXAMPLE_CONTEXT: People can walk but fish cannot.
You can break a tooth if you bite on hard food.
The story he is telling is true.
One plus one is two.

DESCRIPTION: ^See full meaning description.*
EXAMPLE_CONTEXT: ^See full meaning description.*
He was pushing and pulling the furniture around the room.
Is it wet or dry?
He was pushing and pulling the furniture around the room.
There is a white cloud in the sky.

DESCRIPTION: ^See full meaning description.*
EXAMPLE_CONTEXT: ^See full meaning description.*

DESCRIPTION: ^See full meaning description.*
EXAMPLE_CONTEXT: ^See full meaning description.*
There is a tree beside the house.
He threw a stick into the water.
He ate something bad and threw up (vomited).
It was heavy so it was hard to turn it.
The two men are fighting outside.
Only one person at a time can pass through the gate.

DESCRIPTION: Transitive verb, 'playing' a game for amusement.  *Not* 'playing' a musical instrument.
EXAMPLE_CONTEXT: They’re playing a game outside.
Four plus one is five.

DESCRIPTION: The noun '(a) stick' (e.g. of wood), not the verb for to adhere.,
EXAMPLE_CONTEXT: He carried a stick under his arm.
He held the stone in his hand
Who killed this dog?
The year is almost over.
Egg yolk is yellow
When the ground is dry, you kick up dust when you walk.

DESCRIPTION: The noun '(a) wind', /wind/, not the verb /waind/.
EXAMPLE_CONTEXT: She felt the wind in her face.
Birds have wings; people do not.
I saw him walking with a friend.
I saw a man and a woman.
There is a worm in this (insert name of local fruit).
I haven't seen him today but I saw him yesterday.
